text: my favorite west side go to excellent bolognese when they offer it on special...nice staff

Very average overly price food. I personally found the food just ok, portion are small and overprice. I love a fine italian restaurant but this one was barely ok. Service was just okay too, waiter did not expand any specific recommendations! Not worth it

Tarallucci E Vino is a great spot to have a early morning, low-key brunch. I enjoyed the eggs and polenta dish (polenta squares topped with poached eggs, mushrooms and parm), while my friend enjoyed her salmon and egg dish (salmon, kale, and poached eggs on toast).  The toast with butter and jam was also scrumptious.  We didn't try them, but the pastries looked excellent.  Sadly for me, they don't serve cold brew - and iced coffee is just not the same.

Gosh, where to start?!?! This establishment is low-key, yet warm, welcoming and elegant!!! I was in NYC for a work conference and my husband and I were exploring the nieghborhood when we found Tarallucci E Vino. As a birthday treat, my husband suggested that we eat here.The atmosphere is quiet with sensual yet relaxing music in the background. There is a U-shaped bar in the middle with small sit down tables surrounding it. The staff was subdued yet warm and friendly. The dim lights created a romantic feel for our dinner.I am currently pregnant so kept to water for my drink, but my husband ordered the Pink Pepper Italian Beer. He really enjoyed the flavor!! the wine list is extensive, which is really nice!To start we ordered the meatballs. They were perfectly cooked and served with plenty of marinara sauce. Perfect for dips your bread in. The order came with approximately four meatballs. We split an order of the lasagna, which was the perfect size for us to share. If you are hungry, this  better suited for one person. Overall, we had a wonderful time and I would high suggest stopping by!

Was recommended by a friend of mine to dine in this location for brunch and I am VERY pleased. From the moment I walked in I was greeted by the hostess who searched for a table for my partner and myself quickly. After being seated Victoria approached the table and was very accommodating when it came to my allergies; she extremely knowledgeable on food items. My partner also has a particular taste in wine and both barista's were at such great help with finding the right wine for him. Over all, wonderful experience and I'm looking forward to coming back.
Lovely small place. Had a great time with the kids. Wonderful service. The lasagna and the tagliata  were both great. We enjoy our time here. Thanks

This restaurant/wine bar is very low-key yet elegant and impeccably clean. The music selection is often sensual and relaxing. I always come here to meditate over a bowl of fresh pasta after my monthly facial at Savor Spa, which is right across the street. I dated an Italian (Torinese) for three years, and trust me, this is as authentic as it gets in Manhattan!  I am not sure if they make the spaghetti from scratch, but every time I finish my bowl I want to cry (and am one glass of wine away from ordering another bowl). The only thing that keeps me disciplined is knowing that I will be back again in four weeks. Enjoy my spaghetti shoot below.
Portions are small but everything is so good. Wait staff was very friendly. Wine list was extensive.

I can't believe that I missed this gem for the past year even though I live quite close by! It has a beautiful layout. U shaped bar surrounded by sit down tables. For happy hour 5-7 pm, you can order oysters for $1.50 each and spritzers and wines for $9 and below. We ordered 2 dozen oysters and they were deliciously fresh! Went really well with the white house wine.For main, my dad ordered the risotto and I ordered the spaghetti. I love ordering spaghetti at Italian restaurants as I find it the purest Italian dish to judge how well the food is prepared. It was scrumptious; had that bouncy quality that only homemade spaghetti can have. The risotto was rich and delicious too- came with butternut squash and sausage mixed within the creamy sauce.For dessert, we split the tiramisu (as we always do when eating Italian.) So gooood!  I will be back for sure

Great place for a quiet drink in the middle of the day. I've been to their other locations downtown for food but I've only come here for midday drinks. It's a nice quiet spot to have a glass of wine solo or with a friend.

Quaint spot in Upper West Side. We went here for a quick brunch on Thanksgiving day (and hence got a place to sit immediately). The ambiance, service and most importantly food is amazing. Their Uova E Salmone and French Toast are delicious and are a must have.
What a gem! We stopped for lunch after walking in Central Park and it was fantastic. The lentil soup was to die for! And Rita was so sweet. Bravo!
Delicious and atmospheric yet casual. Really great wine Brunello di something. And amazing, simple spaghetti. Lovely.

We came here for lunch after visiting the Natural History Museum. There are tables outside and inside plus at the bar. We picked a table inside.The server was friendly and knowledgeable, but he was the only one working the floor so it took a while for him to get back around to the table. The different wines we had were good quality. The food we had was great. The tomato/pea soup was creamy and thick, definitely filling enough with some bread for dipping. The meat/cheese plate options are great quality. And the spaghetti was as it should be.We also had dessert. The tiramisu was the classic recipe and was up to standard. The berry sorbet was delicious, would definitely recommend this one!All in all we had a great experience here and would definitely recommend this place!
Great breakfast and service. Incredibly friendly and fast services. We had a quick brunch there and it was very tasty. Excellent egg dishes and drinks. The staff was fantastic. We will be back!

My girlfriend and I stopped by on a nice Friday summer evening and sat outside.  From the beginning, it was obvious that the waitstaff was aloof and seemingly untrained.  Our actual waitress didn't seem to care about our existence.  When our plates came, we both were surprised by the tiny portion sizes.  My girlfriend had the Octopus Gnocchi.  At $24, she expected more than a tiny plate of pasta.  I had the scallops which was worse - for $32 I was served four small scallops and five short stems of asparagus.  To be fair, everything was delicious.Tarallucci needs to train their staff better to warrant their high prices and small portion sizes.  At the end of our meal, our waitress brought us the dessert menus.  She then brought us the check without asking if we wanted dessert.We promptly settled our bill and picked up a sushi roll down the street since we both were still hungry.I will not be back to Tarallucci.

I had the chance to try this popular restaurants location in the Upper West Side on a breezy Thursday morning. I've been to their spot in NoMad for dinner, so I was curious to see what they'd be cooking up on their breakfast menu. Needless to say, it was just as good as my dinner experience! It definitely should be an option for anyone looking for a quaint & relaxing breakfast experience in the neighborhood.We arrived to the restaurant around 10 AM on a Thursday morning. We hadn't made a reservation, but it didn't seem like we needed to. There were a lot of table options both inside and outside at this time and they allowed us to pick where we wanted to sit.The space itself is really great! They have tables outside in a sectioned off area on their front sidewalk, as well as indoor seating. On this particularly nice day they had opened the windows which allowed a cool breeze to flow throughout the space. So nice!When it came time to order I went with the Ouva Al Tartufo ($15). Think of is as a well dressed breakfast sandwich with the addition of Truffle Aioli. So freaking good. I came in hungry and this definitely hit the spot. It also comes with a side of home fries, which honestly are just potato bits...The service here was great! The staff was attentive and gave us ample time to look over the menu. They were quick to fill our water glasses and happy to answer any questions we had about the menu.This restaurant is a great option for a low key breakfast in the UWS. Quick and good service, along with a variety of traditional options will undoubtedly leave you satisfied after dining here.
Great food. Even better service! Big thank you to my server, bartender and wonderful server assistant, Freddy. Made my night perfect. Just a wonderful atmosphere. Will always come back.

My bf and I were in the UWS looking for apartments, and decided that I wouldn't make it back to the east village alive without eating something first. This place looked good (read: had pasta) so we popped in for impromptu dinner and wine I a Wednesday evening. We were seated immediately by the window where I proceeded to spy on all the dogs walking by. I ordered the spaghetti and Pinot Grigio and the bear had the duck ragu dish and a Cabernet while sharing the broccolini side dish. The portions were perfect, the spaghetti was delicious in the way where the tomato sauce was not even remotely acidic but perfectly balanced between sweet and tangy. My bf didn't speak at all during the meal which I took to mean he enjoyed himself immensely. The broccolini was lightly and simply cooked so that it was crunchy and a great foil to the rich pasta. Between the food and the delicious wine, we were totally blissed out and wanted to move to the neighbourhood just to be closer to this spot. The environment was relaxed, cute and natural. A bit small so I could see there being a wait during busy hours.

Super cute, convenient. Just wanted aGlass of wine before heading tot the museumOn a Sunday. Saw it on yelp, it's close by so headed over. Sat at the bar, quick service, the wine menu is great, had a glass of algianico (earthy but mild) was delicious. After my museum trip we need a caffeine kick so came over for some americanos, delicious coffee too. Would recommend

Tarallucci has always been a favourite of ours -!I love coming here with my family and am here way too often. The food is fabulous and service never fails. Matias especially was so willing to help and was there whenever we needed him. Five stars all around!!

The service here is bad if you eat in. It seems like staff are very frustrated or disinterested or both and they don't make any effort to hide it. Makes for a bad vibe. We go out to eat on weekends for breakfast and was hoping this could be one of our regular spots since the pastries are good. But the experience was frustrating and not worth the time or money. I could recommend it for quick takeout orders of pastries though since you don't have to be there for the bad vibe.

I went to this restaurant with my two daughters, and they loved it! It is small, but has nice outdoor seating. The pastas are amazing and if you are going there, would definitely recommend. Has a nice atmosphere with friendly servers. If you enjoy Italian food and are in the area, this is the restaurant to go!
This place is the definitely the BEST in the Upper West! They've got very good coffee, pastries are incredibly delicious so is the food and the atmosphere is welcoming!

Great place for a light bite and coffee/wine.    Nice vibe and excellent outdoor sorting on the avenue (weather permitting of course)I had the eggs and polenta with ham while stopping by for breakfast - which was superbService was top notch from Anna and WilliamNext time I am in town, will stop by again !!

I have always admired the outdoor seating at this restaurant and decided to finally pay a visit. This morning, I ordered the poached eggs with asparagus and potatoes and it was delicious! The waiter was also exceptionally kind and helpful. Looking forward to returning.

I have been going to Tarallucchi since it first opened on 18th street 16 years ago. It now covers a lot of ground in the city (literally) with 5 restaurants . On my way to an event at the Naumburg Bandshell last night was an excellent opportunity to stop at the UWS location for salumi e formaggi, which was amazing as usual. The outdoor seating here is more plentiful and better, but my regular haunt on 18th street has a far more inviting dining room. The menus are identical as far as can tell, except the additional lunch and dinner prefix at the Union Square location. The waiters at both places are super knowledgeable about the food and the wine list, which of course is 100% Italian and worth exploring. Our waiter was really nice and got us several wine samples. I settled for Pallagrello Bianco '13 which I wouldn't necessarily have picked out myself, clean and minerally with a touch of fruit.

This is my favorite breakfast/brunch place in NYC. I love it. Delicate pastries, wonderful coffee, and pretty much everything on the menu is fantastic. And we love sitting outside on the patio. Lovely, lovely place.

Just stopped by the cozy spot recently for some oysters and a drink. The oysters were good but I wish they served it with more various sauces. The condiment served with the oyster seemed to be some sort of shallot vinegar. Since the oysters were already served with lemon, I personally thought there could be more body than acid added to the dish. But overall, it was a pleasant experience and will head back to check out their other stuff.
I didnt like the service. Seems like they rushed us to eat because somebody is waiting for a table.

My omelette was rubbery. I asked for ketchup but they didn't have any. I understand wanting to be more sophisticated than a burger joint with bottles out, but at least give me some in a little cup to save my rubbery omelette. Not planning to come back any time soon.

The service in this excellent cafe is impeccable, the food is delicious, and the cappuccinos are the best in NY.  Sara stands out as a superb waitress: she is attentive to details, remembers the usual choices of the regulars, and scans the room when the cafe is busy, in order to meet her customers' needs.  All of the staff are to be commended.Nancy, Ph.D.

European style cafe/restaurant in good taste, with a good wine selection. Authentic Italian dishes served by a friendly staff.  A sufficiently broad menu with good choices in an attractive space for breakfast, lunch or dinner. They make it into more of a wine bar/lively restaurant in the evening. Good vibe. The Barista Rita is charming and makes a superb cappuccino!  A good value and nothing quite like it the UWS.

We had just finished wandering around the American Museum of Natural History and decided to look around the neighborhood for a quick bite to eat.  So we walked two blocks up and came across this diamond.  It so happened to be the perfect food for our last meal in New York.  It is on the corner with floor to ceiling windows making it nice light and open inside even though the size is a little quaint.  The hostess was very friendly and accommodating.  We choose to sit at the bar because all the tables where full and we had time restraints with our departing flights closely approaching.  The barista waited on us and were very attentive.  We had the gnocchi and the meatballs that were on the menu at that time, it appears that the menu has changed since then so I am not sure what the items were called on the menu.  We had a Bellini and mimosa as our appetizer, a lovely glass of red with our meal and an excellent cappuccino to accompany our Italian cookies.  It was a very delightful experience.  If I lived here I would come here often and it is nice to see that they change up the menu for the seasons. Overall the service was excellent the food delivery was prompt the pricing did not break the bank.

Excellent authentic Italian food and very nice place overall. I live nearby and this is our to-go spot for breakfast and brunch. Espresso and cappuccino just like in Italy. And very good Aperol Spritz too.

Came here and had a fine experience.  The place was pretty empty (outside, inside and bar combined).  After sitting at a table for several minutes with no service, we moved up to the bar.  The wines we ordered (rose, sauvignon blanc) were fine.  However, the service was aloof at best.  I had been wanting to try this place for a while - it's so cute!  But I will not be coming back unless a friend specifically asks me to.

Wandering up Columbus Avenue looking for dinner, we stumbled upon this amongst a block of dining choices. What a great choice! The place was pretty full but we were given good attention from our waiter. We had the insalata, gnocchi w pesto, capesante, with a side of asparagus. The best gnocchi I've had in a very long time!!! Great service. Can't wait to return!

The almond croissant was awesome! But weren't enough for all three of us (only two left and we were there just shortly after noon). The service was great though and I really liked the layout of the place.

we will never know...not very busy Saturday night at about 930 ;.four of us walk by and decide that this seems to be a nice place for some pasta and  wine...wonderful hostess sets up table for us outside on a beautiful summer night and we think, hey , maybe we found a gem...waitress hands us menus and wine list...mumbles about a ravoioli/gnoochi special ( i'm not sure); I ask if there is a house wine...there isn't; a low end montepuciano for $54 and a lower end italian chardonnay for $64... gripes...i say, give us a few minutes.....the four of us decide on apps, pastas and wine....the waitress never returns....she was busy in conversation at the bar....no bread , no water refill...no chance to even order...I say why brother...we get up and leave...they couldn't care less.....so why should we...there are plenty of places within a 2 minute walk from here....we went up the street to bellini had a great meal and a fine time....
Okay food. Not a lot of vegetarian options. Spaghetti was fine, dessert was really good though!!

This is one of the most pleasant places to lollygag on the Upper West Side. As the years go by, the constancy of the local team becomes a comfort. Local or not, the restaurant's casual, yet modern, bistro design is a delight. The atmosphere here is almost always bright and festive. While the food has come a long way, it still has a way to go. The caprese and burrata salad was excellent. The bread selection was good, but a little hard (with no butter). Our waiter was friendly and efficient. His rolling Italianesque accent made canned tuna with mayo, surrounded by pork cold cuts, sound like a good choice. Salads, charcuterie and cheese continue to be your best bets here.

This was a nice spot and the wine list was fantastic. Service was a little slow and although the pasta was cooked to perfection, it was a little salty. Overall a nice place but nothing to write home about.

Lovely place to stop by on a blustery, cold morning!  Although M and I didn't take advantage of its brunch offerings, the waitstaff were super gracious. We sat at the bar, drank hot coffee and sampled a biscotti and a cookie from their many carby offerings.I'd love to come by and eat some time.  Lovely, cozy, bright place!

Ok so we had other plans we wanted to originally go to Jacobs Pickles a whole other bag of tricks.  Well it was nuts a line out the door.  So we wandered from place to place.  We were starving so we chose this place.  We couldn't even read the menu and didn't check the Yelp.  Well it ended up being really nice! We got a nice window seat, a great bottle of wine and great food! My hubs got the  gnocchi with pesto and I got the spaghetti. It  was the perfect amount.  It was fresh  and delicious.  Great desserts too!  I had a romantic meal with my babe.  Try it out for yourself!!

Went here for lunch today with a coworker who ordered the spaghetti and I had the lasagna.  Food was alright but service was lacking.  Portions were pretty small for a $17 bowl of spaghetti and $18 lasagna.  The food took awhile (presumably because the lasagna is baked), but they never brought us bread.  Another table which appeared to be an Italian family with kids were brought bread and oil.  My coworker found a thin piece of metal, possibly from one of those pot scrubbers, and instead of asking her what she wanted done about it, they whisked away the dish and remade it.  Nothing taken off the bill.  Just a short apology.  Won't be back.

Nice environment. Would say it's good for a date night. Just had drinks with a friend which I thought was a bit expensive. 13$ for a glass of red wine. Didn't try the food. Bartender was nice enough to give me a sample but wouldn't say she was particularly friendly.

I had a really rude waitress when I had breakfast there. She ignored me most of the time and only paid me attention when the busboy told her to. She shoved the croissant on the edge of the table without even looking at me, and then didn't bother to bring a plate or knife or anything (I had to ask the busboy for everything). I was really surprised by the whole experience. The only reason I left a tip was in the hope that the busboy got most of it. I suggest you train and monitor your wait staff - and you might have a more appealing and welcoming place for your customers. Until then, I've no reason to return. I can't remember feeling so unwelcome in a restaurant - ever.

After four visits, today's experience inspired a review. Two breakfasts, one dinner and one lunch have left me questioning. There's an attempt here to be cafe, bistro and wine bar; none of them are working, leaving an ambivalent feeling about the ambiance. Morning service has been friendly, but on the other occasions, dismissive or disinterested comes to mind.Today, I ordered a pasta and waited about 25 minutes before interrupting the staff meeting taking place next to me at the bar. Not a real meeting, just servers and a possible manager having private conversation, seemingly unaware of my presence. When I finally asked about my order (no one asked me) the server asked the manager how long Gnocchi takes, he looked at me and said 10 minutes. When I said I had been there 25, he just turned and went back to his conversation with the other server.My order was never put in, my server had disappeared and the one left startedto put my order in, when I said 'No, thanks.' and walked out. She did tryto apologize as I grabbed my coat. Manager, nothing.Two stars because the food is good.
Nice bistro cafe on The upper west side. Perfect place for brunch. The food is on point.

Sat down at the bar today (12/3/15 @ 1030am), hoping for a bite and a double espresso.  Two employees - a short-bearded short guy with an Italian accent and young brunette gal - were discussing the staff schedule.   So I patiently waited.  The guy looked over and made eye contact with me, so I thought that meant he was about come get my order.   But I was wrong.  So I waited.  And after 5 minutes of not even being greeted, I walked out.  Lots of other restaurants in the neighborhood who will happily serve me!  Ciao Tarallucci E Vino!

Tarallucci E Vino is an amazing tapas spot.  You can order a full meal but I recommend sitting at the bar and enjoying the vast selection of Italian wines here.  From Barolo to Arneis they have have it all.  Ask for Chris the bartender and you will have exceptional service as well
I really enjoyed my meal here.  I had the raviolis (which came in a wine and speck sauce).  The olive bread was pretty good, and the service was good as well.

The carpaccio salad was impressive, yet didn't offer unique flavors that would entise me to repeat.  The complementary bread and olive oil with a cream of black olives,  was a good pair with the salad.The wine prices seemed a bit pricey for a restaurant which does not have an upscale staff or decor.  Violetta the bar-tender appeared antentive and approachable. None the less, when she refilled my water, she may have forgotten that I originally said yes, when she asked if I wanted ice with my water, and the ice was now melted.I wouldn't mind returning, on a date or with friends.  The open doors and outside seating is quiet inviting for this season.  Would just go for wine.

Delicious, interesting, and well-executed food and a great place to sit outside. We've gotten the prosciutto , bresaola and salmon paninis as well as seared scallops and risotto. All good and would get again.I think the prices are too high for the casualness of the restaurant. Since when did $25+ per plate become the norm?

I came here twice.The first time I came, the food was ok.I wouldn't say that it was pretty good, it was just acceptable. But I had really liked atmosphere, and that's why I came again today, for lunch.This time, the food was terribble!!First, I had some carpaccio. It was really just discusting!! I eat carpaccio at other restaurants all the time, and almost always, I am satisfied. I never felt discusted by this dish before. So congratulations to the chef, you have made me experience a "first"!After the terrible starter, I had the spaghetti with tomato and basil. And it was the worst spaghetti I have ever eaten in my life! There was no salt, like zero salt, and the spaghetti was basically "swimming" in excess tomato sauce!!! I don't understand why anyone would put so much tomato sauce, you don't have to be a master chef to see that it was too much, you can basically see that it was too much just by looking at it! But apparently, this chef doesn't really give a damn about it, so he/she just accepted to serve this ridiculous dish.It was so terrible, I couldn't even finish it, and I left the restaurant hungry.I strongly discourage you from coming here for food. You can, however, come here for drinks. It has a nice atmosphere. But food, please don't do this to yourself.

I just had the most wonderful lunch while sitting at the bar here. The squash risotto with prosciutto is delicious and you have to try the tiramisu. If you're in the area, it is definitely worth your while to stop in for a quick bite and a glass of wine. Great service and a wonderful atmosphere, enhanced by a nice choice of music. I'll definitely be back!
Excellent expressos and food. Rita is wonderful.

The atmosphere and wait staff is very nice but the food was unseasoned.  I mean really unseasoned-undressed salads and the expensive steak had no seasoning at all-I don't think i ever tasted unseasoned meat-it tastes like COW. Maybe the busboy was cooking but they lost our business (and all friends) for ever-note to restaurants on not so busy nights...not having a chef is never a good idea.

Summary: authentic Italian comfort food and friendly service in a romantic low-key space.Coming in out of the rain on a mid-October weeknight, the hostess's warm welcome helped set a good tone.  Tasty breads arrived quickly at the table. We shared a yummy arugula salad.  GF ordered a plate of grilled scallops (capesante) and I had rabbit ragout on pasta (fregnacce).  Decent  Italian wines paired well with the food.  Service was pleasant and attentive. Tab was reasonable.Worth a return visit!

Came here for a glass of wine and sat at the bar. Ordered the meatballs and they were delicious along with the wine! The bartenders gave me great suggestions and the place is super cute. A great date place or if you just want to enjoya glass of vino solo!

We decided to try this place on a whim, walking around the UWS doing errands. Boy are we glad we stopped in! Everything as super fresh, service was friendly and very European (no rushing, ask for the check, etc.). Also, the space is clean  and cozy at the same time - clean lines, little shelves lined with small plants.The bread basket has three types of bread - rosemary focaccia, whole wheat and baguette, and is served with a small pot of oil and olive paste. Delish!Our brunch consisted of the Asparagi and poached eggs with pink peppercorn over potatoes. Amazing tasting, very filling, lovely flavors. The asparagus was cooked just right - still crisp but not stiff. The other dish was the soup and half panini. I'd never heard of Beet Soup but decided it was interesting enough to try. It was so delicious - it had the sweetness of beet but also tasted like fall due to a spicy edge and earthiness to it. I couldn't believe it was vegan! The half pannini was chicken, greens, and the olive pate. It was great, though the chicken was a little on the dry side. The sandwich seemed more like a whole versus a "half." Totally stuffed after.The OJ here is fresh squeezed and tastes like the very essence of an orange.$30 for two, no booze, tax included = a great deal. We'll be back.Amazing beet soup!

This is a great place for pasta, charcuterie, cheese, and wine at a fair price. This is my favorite italian in the UWS. I love the cheese assortment option, it comes with nice toppings. They have a tiny dining room, but some outside tables. It's on a nice block, with Congregation Rodeph Sholom right down the block.

Immediately after walking in a Friday night my party of 3 thought we would love this place. It is clean, intimate and it has outdoor seating (which I LOVE, on hot summer days in NYC). However the food had no taste which made our dinner extramural boring (taste vise). We will most likely not be returning for dinner.The staff was friendly enough, they followed up with drinks, answered our questions about the food in a nice way before we ordered, but we were overall disappointed by the food in the end. I have a strict policy of not sending food back unless it is something wrong with it, or if it was not what I ordered so we all just stuck it out. Both my friends had the Tagliatelle, and I had the Vegetable Lasagna .Like I said, the place look great, it has an ideal location and the staff is friendly. We might come back just to brows through their wine list on a late afternoon. I can imagine this being an ideal spot for a drink after work especially if you get to sit outside.

Got there at 7:30am and was disappointed to find that breakfast didn't start until 8am. But this actually worked out because I was able to have both breakfasted and pastries.We ordered a sugar donut, a cinnamon role, and cornetti. I really liked everything but my sister and mom didn't really care for the cornetti because of the zingy taste that most Italian breads have. So if you don't really like that flavor I would recommended this place. For breakfast we ordered french toast and vegetable frittata. Again the french toast had a zingy taste that some people don't like, but I don't really mind it. I though it was really good. The frittata was also pretty good and the ice coffee was the best part of the whole meal.Only complaint: such slow service, like unbearably slow. No one came to our table to check on us and there were no chances of getting refills.
Very pleasant spot for weekend brunch. The PLT sandwich is great, poached eggs on polenta were a bit heavy for my taste.

I was skeptical to try this spot on a Sunday afternoon (Mother's Day with my husband and MIL) because of the 3.5 stars and because nobody was sitting outside although it was beautiful. However, I'm very glad we came here. The service was efficient and extremely friendly and the food was very good. We had the calamari, which was OK -- not the best we've ever had, but good. Our lobster ravioli was very good, and my MIL's chicken piccata was delicious. The salad was good, too. Also, the wine prices were very reasonable. The atmosphere inside seemed really nice, and the patio was great.
The best place in the neighborhood !Thank God they decided to open one near us!!!I feel very lucky!
This is a great place for coffees and pastriesin the morning. All the staff is extremely polite and helpful !

Went to a wine bar, didn't order wine. Sounds like a meme in the making.The ambiance and location of this place are supreme, but the food isn't memorable. Still a good time though!Our group of six started off with complimentary bread, oil, and olive paste (yelp.com/biz_photos/tara…), which was the perfect appetite stimulant.My friends ordered a QUICHE, $9 (yelp.com/biz_photos/tara…); the TOAST ALLA FRANCESE, which is brioche French toast, bananas, mascarpone cream, $10 (yelp.com/biz_photos/tara…); and some white wines.I chose the UOVA E PORCHETTA, which is poached eggs, grilled porchetta, soft polenta for $10 (yelp.com/biz_photos/tara…). The yolk from the pierced poached eggs fused well with the creamy polenta topped with grated Parmesan cheese. The porchetta was decently salty, a welcome component to this enjoyable, modestly filling dish. It wouldn't fill up large appetites, though.Okay, admission time. Wanna know the real reason why I didn't order wine? I glow like crazy, and as much as I like coordinating outfits, I didn't find it necessary to match the red fall colors in Central Park. Hmph.

Excited to have a place with a downtown feel in the neighborhood.  Delicious wine, delicious tagliatelle, delicious scallops, excellent service, but horrible bruschetta...like bland baby food horrible.  Other than that, love love!

5 star coffee4 star croissant1 star barista attitudewas refered by a regular of this place who told me to stop there since i was staying in UWSgreat lattè, flacky croissant, but still can't get over the "shitty" attitude of u Mrs behind the counter... u don't like tourists? u didn't like my Canada hat? was it too hard to say goodbye? i know, smiling is not for everyone :)i wanted to try this place out also for dinner but tkx to U, i went somewhere else!!grazie millearrivederci

Such a neighborhood gem!  Great food and drink, but above all, the service is exceptional.  After two visits, I was asked if I was having my "usual" (The panini Urano) I feel so well taken care of every time I visit.  I relish every opportunity to enjoy this neighborhood favorite!

Stopped in a quick lunch today. I have to say, this is definitely to place to be on a nice day in the afternoon. It was so pleasant to sit at one of the tables by the window, have a relaxing lunch and watch the world go by. I loved the atmosphere - it was the perfect café setting. Their lunch menus have paninis for $12 which is a pretty good deal. I ordered the rosemary chicken, arugula and black olive spread one. It was delicious. The flavors balanced nicely, the rosemary was not overpowering which it sometimes can be. It was a good sized sandwich for lunch. The bread was delicious, however it was alittle too crunchy for my taste - like cut the inside of your mouth crunchy Who knows, maybe I just have a weirdly sensitive mouth? The bread was tasty though despite texture. Service was good and not rushed. The espresso to finish the meal was tasty and only 2 dollars. Overall a great experience. Seems like a nice neighborhood joint.
Great placeLike been in Italy with friendsGrande Rita e i suoi superbi cappuccini!Love it!Thank you for choosing the UWS we feel lucky !
Ok , nothing special, I guess given the name I expected something more authentic.But decent anyway.

People are always here, sitting outside, luring you in because they seem to be really enjoying themselves.  BUT this can only be because of the wine.  Went here for dinner and tried two entrees.  I had the steak.  It was not delicious.  Not at all.  Sit outside, maybe drink a glass. Maybe light snacks? That is all.

Wow! Great wine list, terrifically delicious octopus carpaccio, yummy duck ragu with freshly made pasta, and tender, tasty rib eye with arugula, tomatoes (not confit), pine nuts, and vinagarette. Finished with tiramisu and coffee. Overpriced? Only before you eat it it and realize it was made fresh to serve and the ingredients are above average. Sour mozzarella? I think not. Could have been your wine or lack of experience with true fresh mozzarella. We will be coming back for great service and delicious food. PS The ambience was lovely!

I love this place. I love the fact that both Rita and Angela know my coffee preference before I even walk in the door. It's just a wonderful place and the occasional Matt Dillon sighting is an added bonus!
I have found my new favorite lunch spot! The food is amazing, wine is very good, and service is friendly. I will be coming here often.

The restaurant is stylish and cute, but too bad the food is awful.  For an app, we had the mozzarella salad;  the cheese had a sour taste to it.  The scallops also tasted off--could only eat one on the four--and the lasagna should be named something like a small plate of inedible vegetables with a few noodles in between.  The menu is very limited and very overpriced.   The only positives are that there are always tables available outside, even on the nicest of NYC nights, and there's a great bread basket that helps to take away the taste of anything else that you are served.   Waitress was sweet and helpful and served the (terrible) food very quickly, but likely because the restaurant was empty.

While I am not yet in the position to offer commentary on the food, I can on the experience as a habitué of the wine bar, and it was indeed enjoyable.This area of Manhattan largely offers a number of sophisticated, alcohol-infused, hideaways, and Tarallucci E Vino is no different; however what drew us in from the beginning were the large windows boasting a well-lit inerior that gazed out on to Columbus Avenue and its passerbys on this rainy evening.The wine-list by the glass is unique, but at the sametime limiting, or perhaps it is my own flawed-paradigm that believes a glass of malbec or a grenache has reached the "taken for granted" heights of off-color staples on the wine list in major cities.  That being said, it forced (ha, "forced") me to try the Argiano non-confuditor (blend); a widely well received and reviewed red with a unique flavor and rich tannins.  I think chianti drinkers would appreciate it, since chianti is not on the menu.The experience at Tarallucci E Vino is worth returning for.  The atmosphere is convivial and casual, and it allowed for "easy to have (and hear)" conversation between my proofreader and I.  The prices by the glass range from $8.00 to $18.00.  Though I did not sample any of the food, those eating around us seemed to be enjoying it and it was all well presented.

Completely love this place. We found this place last summer- perfect location on UWS to sit outside, people watch, nibble and enjoy incredible wine. We recently revisited and it was even better than we remembered. The huge windows were all open so even sitting inside at the bar felt like being outside. The ambiance was so welcoming and open, we stayed much longer than we should have!We weren't familiar with the wines on list but the bartender guided us to the perfect selections. We simply gave a description of what wines we usually drink and they presented us with both red and white that we totally enjoyed. The food menu is simple but varied. We ordered a cheese plate to start and I love that we got to choose which ones we wanted- huge selection! We opted to order all apps so after cheese we had the pollipo and scallops. The pollipo was amazing but the scallops are beyond words- delicious doesn't even begin to describe. They get 5 stars for outstanding service, melt in your mouth food and hands down, the best wine selection in the city.

Cute little restaurant/wine bar, with attentive service. I ordered a glass of sauvinon blanc, which was good. They serve a little basket of bread (foccacia, some kind of sweet raisin bread, and a white bread) with olive oil and a black olive tapanade, which ended up becoming my meal because it was significantly better than the entree I ordered. I ordered the butternut squash risotto, and I wish I hadn't. It came out a few minutes after I ordered it so I should have guessed, at literally the same time when I got the bread. The risotto was bland, and had 4 slices of the cheese placed on top of it. I attempted to stir it into the risotto thinking that it would melt, but no such luck. Perhaps the risotto wasn't hot enough? I would probably return here to try more of the wines, but not for the food.

Sorry to say, but this place was somewhat disappointing for two reasons:1) The wine -  Unsure of what to drink, our waiter very graciously let us sample a couple, neither of which did we like.  No big deal, we decided to pony up for an $18/glass barolo which we are certain to like.  I'm not sure how any Sommelier could have put this wine on their menu, let alone charge $18 for it -- it was so dull and underwhelming, it may as well have been a pinot noir (no offense to pinot noir).  Also, I don't know what the pricing formula is for charging by-the-glass, but after researching the wine on the internet, it seemed disproportionate.2) The food - I won't go as far to say it was bad, but there was really nothing special about it.  We ordered the spinach salad with raspberry dressing - the only thing raspberry about it was the garnish and it was so heavily salted that it was crunching in my teeth.  I'll give them the benefit of the doubt, that it could be a one-off issue, I've done that myself.  We also ordered mozarella di bufala that I was assured was very fresh but it was definitely some store-bought mozarella -- which is fine, I just found it to be disparate with an $18 Barolo.  I will credit them that the roasted veggies that came with it were very good.  This is kind of a small sample to judge the entire menu but we decided not to order anything else after being underwhelmed with our first two choices.  Yelp equates 2 stars with "meh" and that pretty much hit the nail on the head.

Great spot for a low key, leisurely brunch in the Upper West Side. The food is by no means "life changing" and there are certainly tastier options in the neighborhood, but it was solid brunch fare at a really reasonable price without egregious wait times. We sat at the bar/counter in the middle of the restaurant and was given excellent, attentive, friendly service by the barista. We didn't feel hurried or pressured at all, which definitely added to the good experience.

Stopped in one evening on my way home from the office and enjoyed some lovely plates at the bar and had an excellent conversation with the knowledgable maitre d'. Delicious wine and friendly staff made for an enjoyable evening.

This is a review for their breakfast..... It's a great cute spot with delicious coffee, pastries and cheap tasty breakfast items ($5 for ham and cheese croissant). We ate outside but I saw that they also had a pastry counter/fridge upfront inside. Glad that they decided to include breakfast in their usual wine bar/dinner routine - would have eventually stopped by for that, but with a no line brunch on the UWS, I've already been here 2 weekends in a row! Friendly service as well.

Apparently there are several Tarallucci locations, and this one happens to be a wine bar.  I came here for breakfast (and didn't drink wine), so perhaps I did get to have the best they have to offer.  With my love for salmon, I went for the Smoked Salmon Breakfast Panini (photo: yelp.com/biz_photos/tara…).  The panini was pretty toasty and crunchy, moreso than I would have liked, and the salmon portion seemed a bit small.  Pair that with a salad portion that may have been a bit larger than the sandwiches, and you have an okay breakfast.

The wine selection is pretty outstanding, as is the cheese list (if just looking to nosh...as my friend and I were when we happened upon this place).  The service was terrible.  It took a very long time for our waitress, Kamaran, to do any sort of follow-up, table maintenance, take a dessert order, etc....

The food at this awesome wine bar is amazing, and the wine selection is also great, I had a veal Fregnache that looked like a crepe made out of pasta and shredded veal, it was quite good...and the cheese's were also good.  The bartender was a very nice gentlemen, except for when he yelled at the waitress that was standing by the bar, I felt bad for the poor girl, bad manners aside it was a great dinning experience on the upper west side

My son and I stopped in for a Saturday lunch, and it was exactly what I wanted. At first I was skeptical because I only saw pastries at the counter, and there weren't any open tables (it's tiny). We took seats at the bar, and were immediately served. My son has a favorite barista who made him the perfect cafe Americano, and she brought us a bread tray with dipping oil and crushed Kalamata olives. My son ordered a sandwich, but I asked if they had any hot soups (a cold soup was on the menu, but it was chilly outside). The server told me about a fresh asparagus soup which was made with chicken stock instead of (the usual) cream, and it was about the most delicious asparagus soup I've ever had. For dessert I splurged with a coconut macaroon---not too big, not too sweet, half of it coated in chocolate. Perfect.

We went here for brunch because we wanted to sit outside and it's always so busy we assumed it was good. The service was pretty bad, no one checked to see how our food was or if we needed more coffee and we had to wait forever for our check. We ordered the PLT and French toast. The French toast was fine. The egg on the PLT was severely over cooked and I had to remove it from my sandwich. I do not plan on returning, there a too many good brunches to be had on the UWS.

I love the location on East 18th Street although it can get noisy, and I'm super pleased there is a location now in the UWS.  I've been here for breakfast, lunch, afternoon espresso, and all the time very pleased with the pastries and panini.  Very friendly staff, clean, good light.
One of my favorite spots on the UWS. Great wine selection, delicious cheeses, attentive service, beautiful ambiance. They also make delicious lattes in the morning.

After a stroll in a park my friend and I wanted to grab a snack. It is a small place and the staff was not that friendly. I brought a bottle water in and the server was like "umm ya we have a policy of having outside drinks on the table...you have to hide that from our sight." Like OK that is weird. I had the ham and cheese croissant and red tea. The croissant was toasted a little too much and was burnt on the top but overall it was good. It is a cute little shop, but not my favorite.

Passing by on a Friday night, Tarallucci looked cozy and upscale without being stuffy. The interiors are well appointed but acoustics can be challenging, as everyone's laughter and chatter seemed to reverberate more than expected. The service was definitely mixed - we waited awhile for our menus, awhile for our order to be taken, and awhile still to ask for the check. I understand giving your clientele the time and space they would want to enjoy a leisurely meal but that does not mean you chat with the other servers and not pay attention to your tables as they try to flag you down. That being said, the food was delicious. We had glasses of the pinot, the risotto, and the insalata. The red was deep and round, while the risotto was a bit stiffer than is preferred but a lovely pumpkin infused dish nevertheless. The insalata was lightly dressed and a good portion. The menu was a bit confusing since it appeared to be small plates but then the last section were entree-sized were higher priced so we assumed they were bigger. The server, whose English wasn't great, didn't explain this very well when we asked but we put it together fast enough.All in all, the food and ambiance was the redeeming quality of the place and we'll be back to try the small plates, however I hope service can be tightened up.

YES YES YES YES YES!!!Went on Saturday night just for a glass of wine on the random. We were walking by and stopped in. We sat at the bar and got served immediately and had 2 Delicious glasses of wine! The gave us some complimentary amouse bouche yummies and they were amazing!You must stop in to the NYC gem. They have cheeses, pastries and atmosphere. Great pop in for a NYC cocktail cheese and wine afternoon!

Stopped by here yesterday for a coffee and a little snack and was pleasantly surprised by this wonderful little space.The place is decorated beautifully and is very esthetically pleasing.We had cappuccinos and some cookies and the luna sandwich, warm nutella on brioche.  All which were wonderful.Will definitely stop by again and would like to try some of the food which looked delicious.

I went there in the morning to get a pastry. There was a customer in front of me, and a couple behind me. I don't know what was going on, but I stood there well over 5 minutes. The lady behind the bar was so slow, was helping the waiter and then proceeded to serve a customer who came in even later, but sat at the bar. At any other place, all three of us would have been asked our order by now.Even though the place looks great, with the poor service and higher prices, I'll be going up a block to another coffee shop.
expensive over priced crap.....not worth it

Very happy they opened a location in the UWS. Great neighborhood place for good coffee, casual dinner, wine etc...They have a great selection of cheeses and small plates as well as some delicious espresso!I go to the location in the flatiron often so it's nice I can stay uptown to enjoy this place.

This Italian style restaurant bar caters for everybody during the whole day for breakfast through to the evening for that glass of red wine after a long day, great atmosphere and best of all the establishment will cater a menu for small and large business meeings or for party celebrations. Try any one of the 18 flavored Gelato`s or the 12 flavors of SorbetYou can find another three Tarallucci e Vino restaurant`s around Manhatten being Union Sqaure, East Village and Soho

This part of Columbus has seen some hard times.  Places opening and closing -- makes you feel like a restaurant war survivor, ignoring all the new recruits to avoid making friends with the doomed.   I was pretty sure I would ignore this place too, because it looked Upper East Sidey and snooty.  Like that place next door with the $20 ravioli.  Besides being new to the neighborhood, this one also has the gall to make it impossible to spell or remember their name.  "That new wine bar, Tombe Douche E Vino?"  Plus, I prefer wine at home, and small plate craptacular establishments confuse and frighten my wallet.  I doubt I'll ever come here for dinner.  Strike three?Well, my girlfriend and I were in the mood for a new brunch place, and after looking at the menu, took a chance.  This stuff is delicious.  I give it four stars instead of five because we've only been there once for brunch (as I said, the Vino part might as well not exist for me), but my experience was worth mentioning.  The coffee/espresso drinks are great, as they should be at a Nouveau Italienne place, and the people eating pastries looked happy, as happy as the pastries looked delicious.  No problems at all with service (in fact they were very accommodating to our worried "soft poached please for the love of god soft poached" order). Poached eggs w/ porchetta and polenta:  the polenta was a creamy lake around an island of perfectly runny poached eggs and flavorful thinly sliced porchetta.  A masterpiece of rich, flavorful simplicity.The brioche french toast was a lovely sweet variation on the classic stuffed french toast brunch, and the light cheese stuffing in this case added good balance and a je ne sais quoi taste, a plus over the usual cream cheese.  Most restaurants in this neighborhood have $10 or so brunch dishes (not naming certain more expensive if still tasty brunch places on Amsterdam, and definitely naming the way-overhyped Good Enough to Eat), and this one beats them the same way Kefi does for dinner: with a higher quality-to-price ratio.  All that said, I can't add anything about the dinner and wine scene here.  DO remember Tagliamoochi next time you and your date don't feel like standing in line outside a crowded brunch restaurant.  If you live around here, wake up fifteen minutes earlier on a weekday and try it for a breakfast pastry and cappuccino (or just the pastry and coffee from Joe's).  That's my plan, anyway.

I have no idea why this place is so busy!  I went with a friend after work before heading to a show.  They let us taste a couple of wines before ordering so that went and they were very polite about that.  The wine we ordered was 18 a glass, but it was the only one I could actually drink.No one explained that these were small plates.  I ordered the leg of lamb only to find out that it was more of a ragu, and there wasn't much of it.  Certainly not enough for a meal and not worth the +20 I paid for it.  Really, over 20 dollars for a small plate of stringy lamb?   My friend had something with mushrooms, also a small plate much better in flavor...I can remember if it was a risotto or a ravioli.  Oh yeah, the food wasn't memorable.Anyway, still hungry we ordered 3 cheeses for $14.  When the order came no one bothered to tell us which was which, so we had to ask, not cool.  The cheese, while good, wasn't served with much.  At Wine and Roses you get more things with the cheese such as fruit.  This was pretty bare bones.The bill came to $154 before tip.  Mostly because of the wine, but still, We could have had a lovely dinner at any number of resturants on the UWS for that, and it would have been more enjoyable.  Will stick to Wine and Roses for the foreseeable future.

Wine list is good, bartenders are knowledgeable.This place is actually a coffee, pastry, espresso shop by day and wine and cheese bar by night.  Ambiance is simple and modernThis is a good quiet spot to grab an afternoon coffee or glass of wine.

So glad I came back here in the evening to try out the wine list, remarkable! The list is of course very italian focused and not the usual names that you hear. We relied heavily on the bartender to give us recommendations and all of the picks were spot on. One of the wines was soo good that we spent all of the next day trying to find a place that sells it (Eataly)! Service here is top notch and very friendly. Although there are a few over the top selections, price is very fair. This is the best wine bar I have been to on the UWS thus far.It is a small space but it fits a good number of people. My only complaint about the space was that we got stuck in the back left corner at the bar, in between the restroom and in front of the coffee machine. Avoid this spot if you can. Will need to try the food for visit number three.

I ordered the Mushroom Gnocchi and it was nothing short of awful - the gnocchi was poorly cooked, I'm fairly confident that the mushrooms were canned, and the cheap parmesan cheese didn't help the cause.  I flagged down the waitress and asked if I could change my order to the PLT (pancetta, lettuce, and tomato). She took away the gnocchi and quickly brought out the sandwich. I was a big fan of the idea behind the PLT, but it lacked flavor and there was only a small slice of pancetta between multiple tomatoes and lettuce leafs. The worst part is that they actually charged me for the gnocchi...what?! I was extremely offended by this considering they had only been open for a couple of weeks.Okay, now that that is out of the way.....lets talk gelato! Delicious!!!! My only complaint is that the website leads you to believe that there are over a dozen flavors, but fails to mention that they rotate flavors and only carry 3 at a time. We ordered the Mint Chocolate Chip but they were out of it so we opted for the Hazelnut. Bottom line: Skip the entrees, but if you are brunching on the UWS and find yourself with a post-Bloody Mary sweet tooth stop by for an espresso and gelato.

Stopped in for brunch and found it was a really solid place for the UWS. Light and airy space although a little on the small side (it's more of a cafe setup then a restaurant). They have a full menu and lots of vegetarian options. Coffee was delicious (bonussss points) even if they don't do free refills. Pastries were ridiculously good and baked on-site (more points!) Plates were smaller but the food was delicious and filling. Our one complaint? As more people started coming in the waiters started to panic and rush around. I mean, yes, we did laugh to see them flutter about, but it was really bizarre they couldn't maintain composure when more people walked in. "Sacrebleu! They are storming the cafe gates!" Next time maybe less caffeine for the waitstaff, yes?

small venue, cramped as all get up.  lots of small places and even more wine selection.  dark and loud with an interesting music selection.  some of the plates were DELICIOUS.  some of them were... not so much.  beef carpaccio? stay away.  the raw scallops? not worth it.  the roasted veggie with mozzarella dish? GET IT. we got about 6 plates with a bottle of wine for three people and the result was that we were about $150 short at the end of the night.  the doors open into the walls and in the summer i could totally see this place hopping. i'd come back for ONE glass with a few plates and then go get dinner elsewhere!

There is a surprisingly extensive brunch menu here, with a lot of poorly organized but thoroughly tempting dishes... panini, salads, pasta, frittatas, cheese (the restaurant is a wine bar at night), etc.  I got the mozzarella/tomato/basil panini, which came with a side salad and really filled me up.  It was melted perfectly.  My friend and I shared mint chocolate chip gelato for dessert... wonderful way to round out the meal!The main downfall for me?  No free refills on the coffee or iced tea.  However, I really appreciated that our waitress told me before serving it up and ringing it up.I would like to come here to explore it's wine bariness at some point as well... the wine list looked good!

Tarallucci e Vino just opened up this restaurant and replaced the old Subway sandwich shop which I hear a lot of residents thought detracted from the neighborhood.I went with a couple of friends.  We started with some wine and some of the cheese and charcuterie.  We ordered 5 cheeses - you can order 1,2 or 5 on a plate, and a couple of meats.  They were nice but nothing blew me away. The duo of mortadella had fried meat pops (that's the only way I can describe it).  My friend joked that it tasted like fried spam on a stick.The waitress then showed us the menus again and mentioned the risotto entree which was confusing because the menu looked to be more tapas style.I asked her and she said the menu was in fact tapas style.  We asked for suggestions.  She recommended the risotto special made with red wine and pumpkin with an aged cheese on top.  She also recommended the polenta with duck sauce.  She said the duck sauce was their specialty and that it was the same as in their other locations.  Another dish we were going to order was out so we left it with these two.First the polenta.  The duck sauce was really nice.  the duck was tender and hot but unfortunately the polenta was unseasoned, thin and cold.  It lacked in taste and texture.Next was the risotto. Where do I begin.... the risotto was overworked and stiff.  Too stiff for a proper risotto.  It also came out in 2 minute which means it was sitting there on the stove and they didn't even take time to loosen it with some broth.  Had hey done that, it would have been hot  but it was served warm on a cold plate.  The cheese was also melted on top and not even incorporated into the risotto.  it was like a big slice of cheese that you had to cut with the spoon as you tried to serve the risotto.My friend had a white chocolate mouse that was more like a pudding with a lot of fruit on it.  I had a hot chocolate which was thick, rich and chocolaty but also just warm and not "hot".I always joke that there's 2 things many people want to try but don't know how it is supposed to be made - those are Risotto and gnocchi.  I think I'll now add polenta to that list.This restaurant is new and I think needs some time to get the kinks sorted out.  it may be worth another try in a month or two.
